title: Electric Potential and Energy - 3 charged objects

content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Two charged spheres, each with charge <math alttext="positive uppercase Q" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math>, are held in place on the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis at <math alttext="x equals negative A" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>A</mi></mpadded></math> and <math alttext="x equals positive A" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>A</mi></mpadded></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A small charged object with mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and charge <math alttext="negative lowercase q" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>q</mi></mpadded></math> is released from rest on the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"> <mi>y</mi> </math>-axis at <math alttext="y equals positive A" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>A</mi></mpadded></math>. Gravitational effects are negligible.

In Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, draw bars to represent approximate values of <math alttext="U" overflow="scroll"><mi>U</mi></math> and <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> when the charged object is at positions <math alttext="y equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math alttext="y equals negative A" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>A</mi></mpadded></math>.
